G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 212, §3, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Worcester District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a72.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §2, because the property in question is located within Worcester County.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a habitable condition constitutes a violation of the Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a78A.proposition: G.L. c. 239, §8A (Tenant defenses and counterclaims including breach of warranty and quiet enjoyment).

105 CMR 410.550 & 410.600.proposition: 105 CMR 410.550 & 410.600 (State Sanitary Code – rodent infestation and extermination duties of landlords).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord’s responsibility for interference caused by failure to control conditions under his control).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord can be responsible for substantial interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment where the interference arises from conditions the landlord created and retained the right and ability to control, even if the landlord did not personally cause the disturbance. The court emphasizes that the landlords introduced the lounge, had the contractual right to control its noise, and that the resulting disturbance was the natural and probable consequence of what they permitted, thereby breaching the covenant of quiet enjoyment and effecting a constructive eviction.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent…”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (repeated interference with habitability can violate covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely treats repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions as both a breach of habitability and an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and holds the landlord liable on that basis. The opinion explains that ‘quiet enjoyment’ encompasses serious interferences with the tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, and concludes that Gem’s failure to prevent repeated flooding that rendered the unit non‑watertight and unsanitary constituted an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that repeated interferences with habitability can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute…. Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (implied warranty of habitability and its connection to quiet enjoyment).
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The excerpt is a concurrence/dissent that repeatedly discusses an "implied warranty of habitability," criticizes the old no‑repair rule, and emphasizes that the landlord’s obligation and the tenant’s rent obligation should be mutually interdependent. Although this separate opinion favors tying the landlord’s duty to statutory code compliance rather than a broad, free‑floating warranty, it acknowledges and partly concurs in the majority’s adoption of an implied warranty for residential leases. The connection to quiet enjoyment is more implicit than explicit, so the case supports the implied warranty doctrine, but only indirectly its linkage to quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “Having thus failed to qualify for the defence which would otherwise have been available to them under § 8A, the tenants ask this court to give them relief by holding (a) that the landlord impliedly warranted the fitness of their apartments for habitation, (b) that the landlord violated the warranty, and (c) that the landlord’s obligation to comply with the warranty and their obligation to pay their rent are mutually interdependent.… The opinion of the court accomplishes this.”

Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.raw_text: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003)
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.proposition: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003) (scope of “quiet enjoyment” includes substantial interference).
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.case_name: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.support_reasoning: The opinion in Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy concerns whether counterclaims are procedurally available in commercial summary process actions and how G.L. c. 239, § 8A should be interpreted. It does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment, its scope, or the concept of ‘substantial interference’ with quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that the scope of quiet enjoyment includes substantial interference.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.relevant_excerpt: “We transferred this case here on our own motion to decide whether a counterclaim may be filed in a commercial summary process action, particularly given the adoption of the rule of mutually dependant covenants in commercial leases… Because we agree with the trial judge’s determination that a counterclaim is not a proper procedural device in a commercial summary process action, we affirm the judgment entered in the Superior Court.”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (constructive interference by landlord can establish a breach).
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes that a landlord’s omissions—its failure to act to remove third parties engaged in criminal activity from areas it controls—can amount to a serious interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment and thus breach the covenant. The court explains that liability can arise where such interference is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did or failed to do, and remands to determine whether the landlord’s inaction constituted such a breach. This squarely supports the idea that constructive interference by the landlord (through inaction) can establish a breach.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. … [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies….”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (liability does not require intent where interference foreseeably arises from landlord’s acts or omissions).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion holds the opposite of what the proposition claims. The court makes clear that liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment is not strict and requires at least negligent conduct, including notice or reason to know and foreseeability of interference; a mere statutory violation (like the strict-liability lead paint statute) is not enough. Thus, Al‑Ziab rejects the idea that liability arises without intent or fault whenever interference is merely a foreseeable consequence of a landlord’s acts or omissions.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

Hinson v. O\u2019Connor, 74 Mass. App. C.raw_text: Hinson v. O’Connor, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 1120 (2009)
Hinson v. O\u2019Connor, 74 Mass. App. C.proposition: Hinson v. O’Connor, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 1120 (2009) (uncontrolled pest infestation constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. L. Rptr. 69.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. L. Rptr. 693 (2001)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. L. Rptr. 69.proposition: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. L. Rptr. 693 (2001) (failure to maintain premises free from vermin breaches G.L. c. 186, §14).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. L. Rptr. 69.case_name: Haskins v. President & Fellows of Harvard College
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. L. Rptr. 69.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns disability discrimination in an academic program at Harvard and statutory interpretation of the Public Accommodations Statute and MERA. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, G.L. c. 186, §14, habitability, or vermin infestations. Nothing in the reasoning or holding addresses premises conditions or a duty to maintain premises free from vermin, so it cannot support the cited proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. L. Rptr. 69.relevant_excerpt: By statute, G.L.c. 272, §98, Massachusetts prohibits discrimination based on physical disability in any “place of public accommodation, resort or amusement,” i.e., “any place, whether licensed or unlicensed, which is open to and accepts or solicits the patronage of the general public,” G.L.c. 272, §92A. … Harvard is not a place of public accommodation, and is thus immune to suit under the Public Accommodations Act.
